head.hi:
From the New York Post.
Table Moving in Switzerland—Letter from
Humboldt.

div.p:
A society of table movers in the pious city of
Calvin have recently published, both there and at
Lausanne, a work in two volumes, under the title
of “Rome, Geneva, and the Church of Christ. A
work dictated by the Son of God, the Saviour of
the world, sole mediator between God and man.”
We give the following extract from it:

“God takes once more a table as his medium
for revelations. Every person who appreciates
the freedom with which God has inspired his
breast, will examine everything, and approve of
what is good only. The Genevan is oppressed by
Evangelical despotism. His conscience must be
as free as his arm or his thought. The most
abominable despotism is the despotism of religion,
because it kills not only the body, but the soul.

“Genevans, do you love your fatherland and
your ancient freedom? Will you live up to the
maxim, post tenebras lux, and see the eagle stained
with the blood your ancestors still respected?
Well, then, partake with us of the blessings which
God, with bounteous hand, scatters over our dear
fatherland. Do not, as many do, condemn this
work before you have read and pondered it. Do
even more; compare it with your Gospel, and may
the comparison be undertaken in the spirit of in-
dependence and justice. IN the name of the so-
ciety,

One of the converts of this work is about to dis-
pose of his splendid fortune in a way to prove the
sincerity of his faith in the prophecies it contains
about the speedy destruction of the world.

Some persons reported the author of Kosmos to
be a believer in the mysteries of table-moving, be-
cause he had approved of the theory of the elec-
tricity of the nerves, started by Du Boys Reymonds.
Dr. Jobard thereupon wrote to Humboldt to ascer-
tain his opinion about spiritualism, and received
the following answer:

Berlin, April 2, 1856.—You have written to
me, my dear sir, as you always do, a most amiable
letter, but I am not able to give you my opinion
upon the possibility of the existence to the various
kinds of mineral, vegetable, animal, direct or indi-
rect cerebral electricity. I have a holy horror of
all kinds of pine wood spiritualism and psycho-
graphic mysticisms. You increase my horror by
the ghost of that ephemeric being of reason which
is to receive intelligence from the thoughts of
those persons who surround the table. You know
that Geoffrey Saint Hilaire pretends to have sweat
the oxyde of thought while in Egypt, and you,
my dear friend, will say, that my incredulity is the
simple consequence of my laziness. I submit wil-
lingly to this reproach, for I am convinced that the
friendship, which you always extended to me, will
not be diminished if I can be instrumental in lead-
ing you out of the obscure path of error. I rely
on your forgiveness.
